sp.p: Am I but three inches? Why thy horne is a foot and ſo long am I at the leaſt. But wilt thou make a fire or ſhall I complaine on thee to our miſtris, whoſe hand (ſhe being now at hand) thou ſhalt ſoone feele, to thy cold comfort, for being ſlow in thy hot office.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: I prethee good Grumio, tell me, how goes the world?

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p: A cold world Curtis in euery office but thine, and therefore fire: doe thy dutie, and haue thy dutie, for my Maſter and miſtris are allmoſt frozen to death.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: There's fire readie, and therefore good Grumio the newes.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.l: Why Iacke boy, ho boy, and as much newes as thou wilt.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Come, you are ſo full of conicatching.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p:
Why therefore fire, for I haue caught extreme cold. Where's the Cooke, is ſupper readie, the houſe trim'd, ruſhes
ſtrew'd, cobwebs ſwept, the ſeruingmen in their new fuſtion, the white ſtockings, and euery officer his wedding garment on? Be the Iackes faire wi • hin, • he Gils faire without, the Ca • pets laide, and euery thing in order?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: All ready: and therefore I pray thee newes.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p: Firſt know my horſe is tired, my maſter and miſtris falne out.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p: Out of their ſaddles into the durt, and thereby hangs a tale.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Let's ha't good Grumio.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.l: Lend thine eare.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Heere.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.l: There.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: This 'tis to feele a tale, not to heare a tale.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p: And therefore 'tis cal'd a ſenſible tale: and this Cufte was but to knocke at your eare, and beſeech liſtning: now I begin Inprimis we came downe a foule hill, my Maſter riding behinde my Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Both of one horſe?

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.l: What's that to thee?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Why a horſe.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p: Tell thou the tale: but hadſt thou not croſt me, thou ſhouldſt haue heard how her horſe fell, and ſhe vnder her horſe: thou ſhouldſt haue heard in how miery a place, how ſhe was bemoil'd, how he left her with the horſe vpon her, how he beate me becauſe her horſe ſtumbled, how ſhe waded through the durt to plucke him off me: how he ſwore, how ſhe prai'd, that neuer prai'd before: how I cried, how the horſes ranne away, how her bridle was burſt: how I loſt my crupper, with many thinges of worthy memorie, which now ſhall die in obliuion, and thou returne vnexperienc'd to the graue.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: By this reckning he more ſhrew than ſhe.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p: I, and that thou and the proudeſt of you all ſhall finde when he comes home. But what talke I of this? Call forth Nathaniell, Ioſeph, Nicholas, Phillip, Walter, Sugerſop and the reſt: let their heads bee ſlickely comb'd, their blew coats bruſh'd, and their garters of an indifferent knit, let them curtſie with their left legges, and not preſume to touch a haire of my Maſters horſe-taile till they kiſſe their hands. Are they all readie?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: They are.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.l: Call them forth.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Doe you heare ho? you muſt meete my maiſter to countenance my miſtris.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.l: Why ſhe hath a face of her owne.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Who knowes not that?

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p: Thou it ſeemes, that calls for company to countenance her.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: I call them forth to credit her.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.l: Why ſhe comes to borrow nothing of them.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Welcome home Grumio.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: How now Grumio.

sp.speaker: Ioſ.
sp.l: What Grumio.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.l: Fellow Grumio.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: How now old lad,

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p: Welcome you: how now you: what you: fellow you: and thus much for greeting. Now my ſpruce companions, is all readie, and all things neate?

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: All things is readie, how neere is our maſter?

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: E'ne at hand, alighted by this: and therefore be not—
Cockes paſſion, ſilence, I heere my maſter.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Where be theſe knaues? what no man at doore
To hold my ſtirrop, nor to take my horſe?
Where is Nathaniell, Gregory, Phillip.

sp.speaker: All ſer.
sp.l: Heere, heere ſir, heere ſir.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Heere ſir, heere ſir, heere ſir, heere ſir.
You logger-headed and vnp • lliſht groomes:
What? no attendants? no regard? no dutie?
Where is the fooliſh knaue I ſent before?

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.l: Heere ſir, as fooliſh as I was before.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: You pezant, ſwaine, you horſon malt-horſe drudg
Did I not bid thee meete me in the Parke,
And bring along theſe raſcall knaues with thee?

sp.speaker: Grumio.
sp.l: Nathaniels coat ſir was not fully made,
And Gabriels pumpes, were all vnpinkt i'th heele:
There was no Linke to colour Peters hat,
And Walters dagger was not come from ſheathing:
There were none fine, but Adam, Rafe, and Gregorie,
The reſt were ragged, old, and beggerly,
Yet as they are, heere are they come to meete you.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Go raſcals, go, and fetch my ſupper in. Ex. Ser.
Where is the life that late I led?
Where are thoſe? Sit downe Kate,
And welcome. Soud, ſoud, ſoud, ſoud.
Why when I ſay? Nay good ſweete Kate be merrie.
Off with my boots, you rogues: you villaines, when?

l.hi: It was the Friar of Orders gray,
As he forth walked on his way.

sp.l: Out you rogue, you plucke my foot awrie,
Take that, and mend the plucking of the other
Be merrie Kate: Some water heere: what hoa.
Where's my Spaniel Troilus? Sirra, get you hence,
And bid my cozen Ferdinand come hither:
One Kate that you muſt kiſſe, and be acquainted with.
Where are my Slippers? ſhall I haue ſome water?
Come Kate and waſh, and welcome heartily:
You horſon villaine, will you let it fall?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Patience I pray you, 'twas a fault vnwilling.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: A horſon beetle-headed flap-ear'd knaue:
Come Kate ſit downe, I know you haue a ſtomack,
Will you giue thankes, ſweete Kate, or elſe ſhall I?
What's this, Mutton?

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.l: I.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Who brought it?

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.l: I.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: 'Tis burnt, and ſo is all the meat
What dogges are theſe? Where is the raſcall Cooke?
How durſt you villaines bring it from the dreſſer
And ſerue it thus to me that loue it not?
There, take it to you, trenchers, cups, and all:
You heedleſſe iolt-heads and vnmanner'd ſlaues.
What, do you grumble? Ile be with you ſtraight.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: I pray you husband be not ſo diſquiet,
The meat was well, if you were ſo contented.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I tell thee Kate, 'twas burnt and dried away,
And I expreſſeſly am forbid to touch it:
For it engenders choller, planteth anger,
And better 'twere that both of vs did faſt,
Since of our ſelues, our ſelues are chollericke,
Then feede it with ſuch ouer-roſted fleſh:
Be patient, to morrow 't ſhall be mended,
And for this night we'l faſt for companie.
Come I will bring thee to thy Bridall chamber. Exeunt

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Peter didſt euer ſee the like.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.l: He kills her in her owne humor.

sp.speaker: Grumio.
sp.l: Where is he?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: In her chamber, making a ſermon of continencie to her, and railes, and ſweares, and rates, that ſhe (poore ſoule) knowes not which way to ſtand, to looke, to ſpeake, and ſits as one new riſen from a dreame. Away, away, for he is comming hither.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Thus haue I politickely begun my reigne,
And 'tis my hope to end ſucceſſefully:
My Faulcon now is ſharpe, and paſſing emptie,
And till ſhee ſtoope, ſhe muſt not be full gorg'd,
For then ſhe neuer lookes vpon her lure,
Another way I haue to man my Haggard,
To make her come, and know her keepers call:
That is, to watch her, as we watch theſe Kites,
That baite, and beate, and will not be obedient:
She eate no meate to day, nor none ſhall eate.
Laſt night ſhe ſlept not, nor to night ſhe ſhall not:
As with the meat, ſome vndeſerued fault
Ile finde about the making of the bed,
And heere Ile fling the pillow, there the boulſter,
This way the Couerlet, another way the ſheetes:
I, and amid this hurly I intend,
That all is done in reuerend care of her,
And in concluſion, ſhe ſhall watch all night,
And if ſhe chance to nod, Ile raile and brawle,
And with the clamour keepe her ſtill awake:
This is a way to kill a Wife with kindneſſe,
And thus Ile curbe her mad and headſtrong humor:
He that knowes better how to tame a ſhrew,
Now let him ſpeake, 'tis charitie to ſhew. Exit.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Is't poſſible friend Liſio, that Miſtris Bianca
Doth fancie any other but Lucentio,
I tell you ſir, ſhe beares me faire in hand,

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Sir, to ſatisfie you in what I haue ſaid,
Stand by, and marke the manner of his teaching.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Now Miſtris profit you in what you read?

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: What Maſter reade you firſt, reſolue me that?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I read, that I profeſſe the Art to loue.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: And may you proue ſir Maſter of your Art.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: While you ſweete deere proue Miſtreſſe of my heart.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Quicke proceeders marry, now tell me I pray,
You that durſt ſweare that your miſtris Bianca
Lou'd me in the world ſo well as Lucentio.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Oh deſpightfull Loue, vnconſtant womankind,
I tell thee Liſio this is wonderfull.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Miſtake no more, I am not Liſio,
Nor a Muſitian as I ſeeme to bee,
But one that ſcorne to liue in this diſguiſe,
For ſuch a one as leaues a Gentleman,
And makes a God of ſuch a Cullion;
Know ſir, that I am call'd Hortenſio.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Signior Hortenſio, I haue often heard
Of your intire affection to Bianca,
And ſince mine eyes are witneſſe of her lightneſſe,
I will with you, if you be ſo contented,
Forſweare Bianca, and her loue for euer.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: See how they kiſſe and court: Signior, Lucentio,
Heere is my hand, and heere I firmly vow
Neuer to woo her more, but do forſweare her
As one vnworthy all the former fauors
That I haue fondly flatter'd them withall.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: And heere I take the like vnfained oath,
Neuer to marrie with her, though ſhe would intreate,
Fie on her, ſee how beaſtly ſhe doth court him.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Would all the world but he had quite forſworne
For me, that I may ſurely keepe mine oath.
I will be married to a wealthy Widdow,
Ere three dayes paſſe, which hath as long lou'd me,
As I haue lou'd this proud diſdainfull Haggard,
And ſo farewell ſignior Lucentio,
Kindneſſe in women, not their beauteous lookes
Shall win my loue, and ſo I take my leaue,
In reſolution, as I ſwore before.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Miſtris Bianca, bleſſe you with ſuch grace,
As longeth to a Louers bleſſed caſe:
Nay I haue tane you napping gentle Loue,
And haue forſworne you with Hortenſio.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Tranio you ieſt, but haue you both forſworne me?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Miſtris we haue.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Then we are rid of Liſio.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: I'faith hee'l haue a luſtie Widdow now,
That ſhall be woo'd, and wedded in a day.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: God giue him ioy.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: I, and hee'l tame her.

sp.speaker: Bianca.
sp.l: He ſayes ſo Tranio

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Faith he is gon vnto the taming ſchoole.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: The taming ſchoole: what is there ſuch a place?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: I miſtris, and Petruchio is the maſter,
That teacheth trickes eleuen and twentie long,
To tame a ſhrew, and charme her chattering tongue.

sp.speaker: Bion.
sp.l: Oh Maſter maſter I haue watcht ſo long,
That I am dogge wearie, but at laſt I ſpied
An antient Angell comming downe the hill,
Will ſerue the turne

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: What is he Biondello?

sp.speaker: Bion.
sp.l: Maſter a Marcantant, or a pedant,
I know not what, but formall in apparell,
In gate and countenance ſurely like a Father.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: And what of him Tranio?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: If he be credulous, and truſt my tale,
Ile make him glad to ſeeme Vincentio,
And giue aſſurance to Baptiſta Minola,
As if he were the right Ʋincentio.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Take me your loue, and then let me alone.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: God ſaue you ſir.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: And you ſir, you are welcome,
Trauaile you farre on or are you at the fartheſt?

sp.speaker: Ped:
sp.l: Sir at the fartheſt for a weeke or two,
But then vp farther, and as farre as Rome,
And ſo to Tripolie, if God lend me life,

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: What Countreyman I pray?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Of Mantua.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Of Mantua Sir, marrie God forbid,
And come to Padua careleſſe of your life.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: My life ſir? how I pray? for that goes hard.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: 'Tis death for any one in Mantua
To come to Padua, know you not the cauſe?
Your ſhips are ſtaid at Venice, and the Duke
For priuate quarrell 'twixt your Duke and him,
Hath publiſh'd and proclaim'd it openly:
'Tis maruaile, but that you are but newly come,
You might haue heard it elſe proclaim'd about.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Alas ſir, it is worſe for me then ſo,
For I haue bills for monie by exchange
From Florence and muſt heere deliuer them.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Well ſir, to doe you courteſie,
This will I doe, and this I will aduiſe you.
Firſt tell me, haue you euer beene at Piſa?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I ſir, in Piſa haue I often bin,
Piſa renowned for graue Citizens.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Among them know you one Vincentio?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I know him not, but I haue heard of him:
A Merchant of incomparable wealth.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: He is my father ſir, and ſooth to ſay,
In count'nance ſomewhat doth reſemble you.

sp.speaker: Bion.
sp.l: As much as an apple doth an oyſter, and all one,

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: To ſaue your life in this extremitie,
This fauor will I doe you for his ſake,
And thinke it not the worſt of all your fortunes,
That you are like to Sir Ʋincentio.
His name and credit ſhall you vndertake,
And in my houſe you ſhall be friendly lodg'd,
Looke that you take vpon you as you ſhould,
You vnderſtand me ſir: ſo ſhall you ſtay
Till you haue done your buſineſſe in the Citie:
If this be court'ſie ſir, accept of it.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Oh ſir I doe, and will repute you euer
The patron of my life and libertie.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Then goe with me, to make the matter good,
This by the way I let you vnderſtand,
My father is heere look'd for euerie day,
To paſſe aſſurance of a dowre in marriage
'Twixt me, and one Baptiſtas daughter heere:
In all theſe circumſtances Ile inſtruct you,
Goe with me to cloath you as becomes you. Exeunt.

div.head: Scena Prima.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.l: No, no forſooth I dare not for my life.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: The more my wrong, the more his ſpite appeares.
What, did he marrie me to famiſh me?
Beggers that come vnto my fathers doore,
Vpon intreatie haue a preſent almes,
If not, elſewhere they meete with charitie:
But I, who neuer knew how to intreate,
Nor neuer needed that I ſhould intreate,
Am ſtaru'd for meate, giddie for lacke of ſleepe:
With oathes kept waking, and with brawling fed,
And that which ſpights me more then all theſe wants,
He does it vnder name of perfect loue:
As who ſhould ſay if I ſhould ſleepe or eate,
'Twere deadly ſickneſſe, or elſe preſent death.
I prethee goe, and get me ſome repaſt,
I care not what, ſo it be wholſome foode.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.l: What ſay you to a Neats foote?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: 'Tis paſſing good, I prethee let me haue it.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.l: I feare it is too chollericke a meate,
How ſay you to a fat Tripe finely broyl'd?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: I like it well, good Grumio fetch it me.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.l: I cannot tell, I feare 'tis chollericke.
What ſay you to a peece of Beefe and Muſtard?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: A diſh that I do loue to feede vpon.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.l: I but the Muſtard is too hot a little.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Why then the Beefe, and let the Muſtard reſt.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.l: Nay then I will not, you ſhall haue the Muſtard
Or elſe you get no Beefe of Grumio.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Then both or one, or any thing thou wilt.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.l: Why then the Muſtard without the beefe.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Go get thee gone, thou falſe deluding ſlaue,
That feed'ſt me with the verie name of meate.
Sorrow on thee, and all the packe of you
That triumph thus vpon my miſerie:
Go get thee gone I ſay.

div.stage: Enter Petruchio, and Hortenſio with meate.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: How fares my Kate, what ſweeting all a-mort?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Miſtris, what cheere?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: Faith as cold as can be.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Plucke vp thy ſpirits, looke cheerefully vpon me.
Heere Loue, thou ſeeſt how diligent I am,
To dreſſe thy meate my ſelfe, and bring it thee.
I am ſure ſweet Kate this kindneſſe merits thankes.
What, not a word? Nay then thou lou'ſt it not:
And all my paines is ſ • rted to no proofe.
Heere take away this diſh.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: I pray you let it ſtand.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: The pooreſt ſeruice is repaide with thankes,
And ſo ſhall mine before you touch the meate.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: I thanke you ſir.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Signior Petruchio, fie you are to blame:
Come Miſtris Kate, Ile beare you companie.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Eate it vp all Hortenſio, if thou loueſt mee:
Much good do it vnto thy gentle heart:
Kate eate apace; and now my honie Loue,
Will we returne vnto thy Fathers houſe,
And reuell it as brauely as the beſt,
With ſilken coats and caps, and golden Rings,
With ruffes and Cuffes, and Fardingales, and thinges:
With Scarfes, and fannes, and double change of brau'ry,
With Amber Bracelets, Beads, and all this knau'ry.
What haſt thou din'd? The Tailor ſtayes thy leaſure,
To decke thy bodie with his ruffing treaſure,
Come Tailor, let vs ſee theſe ornaments
Lay forth the Gowne. What newes with you ſir?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Heere is the cap your Worſhip did beſpeake.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Why this was moulded on a porrenger,
A Veluet diſh: Fie, fie, 'tis lewd and filthy,
Why 'tis a cockle or a wallnut-ſhell,
A knack, a toy, a tricke, a babies cap:
Away with it come let me haue a bigger.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Ile haue no bigger, this doth fit the time,
And Gentlewomen weare ſuch caps as theſe.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: When you are gentle, you ſhall haue one too,
And not till then.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: That will not be in haſt.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Why ſir I truſt I may haue leaue to ſpeake,
And ſpeake I will. I am no childe, no babe,
Your betters haue indur'd me ſay my minde
And if you cannot, beſt you ſtop your eares,
My tongue will tell the anger of my heart,
Or elſe my heart concealing it will breake,
And rather then it ſhall, I will be free,
Euen to the vttermoſt as I pleaſe in words.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Why thou ſaieſt true, it is a paltrie cap.
A cuſtard coffen, a bauble, a ſilken pie,
I loue thee well in that thou lik'ſt it not.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Loue me, or loue me not, I like the cap,
And it I will haue, or I will haue none.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Thy gowne why I: come Tailor let vs ſee't.
Oh mercie God, what masking ſtuffe is heere?
Whats this? a ſleeue? 'tis like a demi-cannon,
What, vp and downe caru'd like an apple Tart?
Heers ſnip, and nip, and cut, and ſliſh and ſlaſh,
Like to a Cenſor in a barbers ſhoppe:
Why what a deuils name a Tailor cal'ſt thou this?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I ſee ſhees like to haue neither cap nor gowne.

sp.speaker: Tai.
sp.l: You bid me make it orderlie and well,
According to the faſhion, and the time.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Marrie and did: but if you be remembred,
I did not bid you marre it to the time.
Goe hop me ouer euery kennell home,
For you ſhall hop without my cuſtome ſir:
Ile none of it; hence, make your beſt of it.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: I neuer ſaw a better faſhion'd gowne,
More queint, more pleaſing, nor more commendable:
Belike you meane to make a puppet of me.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Why true, he meanes to make a puppet of thee.

sp.speaker: Tail.
sp.l: She ſaies your Worſhip meanes to make a puppet of her

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Oh monſtrous arrogance:
Then lyeſt, thou thred, thou thimble,
Thou yard three quarters, halfe yard, quarter, naile,
Thou Flea, thou Nit, thou winter cricket thou:
Brau'd in mine owne houſe with a skeine of thred:
Away thou Ragge, thou quantitie, thou remnant,
Or I ſhall ſo be-mete thee with thy yard,
As thou ſhalt thinke on prating whil'ſt thou liu'ſt:
I tell thee I, that thou haſt marr'd her gowne.

sp.speaker: Tail.
sp.l: Your worſhip is deceiu'd, the gowne is made
Iuſt as my maſter had direction:
Grumio gaue order how it ſhould be done.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.l: I gaue him no order, I gaue him the ſtuffe.

sp.speaker: Tail.
sp.l: But how did you deſire it ſhould be made?

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.l: Marrie ſir with needle and thred.

sp.speaker: Tail.
sp.l: But did you not requeſt to haue it cut?

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.l: Thou haſt fac'd many things.

sp.speaker: Tail.
sp.l: I haue.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p:
Face not mee: thou haſt brau'd many men, braue not me; I will neither bee fac'd nor brau'd. I ſay vnto thee, I bid thy
Maſter cut out the gowne, but I did not bid him cut it to peeces; Ergo thou lieſt.

sp.speaker: Tail.
sp.l: Why heere is the note of the faſhion to teſtifie.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Read it.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.l: The note lies in's throate if he ſay I ſaid ſo.

sp.speaker: Tail.
sp.l: Inprimis a looſe bodied gowne.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p: Maſter, if euer I ſaid looſe-bodied gowne, ſow me in the Skirts of it, and beate me to death with a bottome of browne thred: I ſaid a gowne.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Proceede.

sp.speaker: Tail.
sp.l: With a ſmall compaſt cape.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.l: I confeſſe the cape.

sp.speaker: Tail.
sp.l: With a trunke ſleeue.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.l: I confeſſe two ſleeues.

sp.speaker: Tail.
sp.l: The ſleeues curiouſly cut.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I there's the villainie.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p: Error i'th bill ſir, error i'th bill? I commanded the ſleeues ſhould be cut out, and ſow'd vp againe, and that Ile proue vpon thee, though thy litle finger be armed in a thimble.

sp.speaker: Tail.
sp.p: This is true that I ſay, and I had thee in place where, thou ſhouldſt know it.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p: I am for thee ſtraight: take thou the bill, giue me thy meate-yard, and ſpare not me.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: God-a-mercy Grumio, then he ſhall haue no oddes.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Well ſir in breefe the gowne is not for me.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.l: You are i'th right ſir, 'tis for my miſtris.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Go take it vp vnto thy maſters vſe.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p: Villaine, not for thy life: Take vp my Miſtreſſe gowne for thy maſters vſe.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Why ſir what's your conceit in that?

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: Oh ſir, the conceit is deeper then you thinke for:
Take vp my Miſtris gowne to his maſters vſe.
Oh fie, fie, fie.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Hortenſio, ſay thou wilt ſee the Tailor paide.
Go take it hence, be gone, and ſay no more.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Tailor, Ile pay thee for thy gowne to morrow,
Take no vnkindneſſe of his haſtie words:
Away I ſay, commend me to thy maſter. Exit Tail.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Well come my Kate, we will vnto your fathers,
Euen in theſe honeſt meane habiliments:
Our purſes ſhall be proud, our garments poore:
For 'tis the minde that makes the bodie rich.
And as the Sunne breakes through the darkeſt clouds,
So honor peereth in the meaneſt habit.
What is the Iay more precious then the Larke?
Becauſe his feathers are more beautifull
Or is the Adder better then the Eele,
Becauſe his painted Skin contents the eye.
Oh no Kate: neither art thou the worſe
For this poore furniture, and meane array.
If thou accountedſt it ſhame, lay it on me,
And therefore frolike, we will hence forthwith,
To feaſt and ſport vs at thy fathers houſe,
Go call my men, and let vs ſtraight to him,
And bring our horſes vnto Long-lane end,
There will we mount, and thither walke on foote,
Let's ſee, I thinke 'tis now ſome ſeuen a clocke,
And well we may come there by dinner time.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: I dare aſſure you ſir, 'tis almoſt two,
And 'twill be ſupper time ere you come there.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: It ſhall be ſeuen ere I go to horſe:
Looke what I ſpeake, or do, or thinke to doe,
You are ſtill croſſing it, ſirs let 't alone,
I will not goe to day, and ere I doe,
It ſhall be what a clock I ſay it is.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Why ſo this Gallant will command the ſunne:

div.stage: Enter Tranio, and the Pedant dreſt like Ʋincentio.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Sirs, this is the houſe, pleaſe it you that I call,

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I what elſe, and but I be deceiued,
Signior Baptiſta may remember me
Neere twentie yeares a goe in Genoa.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Where wee were Lodgers, at the Pegaſus,
Tis well, and hold your owne in any caſe
With ſuch auſteritie as longeth to a father.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I warrant you: but ſir here comes your boy,
'Twere good he weere ſchool'd.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Feare you not him: ſirra Biondello,
Now doe your dutie throughlie I aduiſe you:
Imagine 'twere the righ Ʋincentio.

sp.speaker: Bion.
sp.l: Tut, feare not me.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: But haſt thou done thy errand to Baptiſta.

sp.speaker: Bion.
sp.l: I told him that your father was at Ʋenice,
And that you look't for him this day in Padua.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Th'art a tall fellow, hold thee that to drinke,
Heere comes Baptiſta: ſet your countenance ſir.

div.stage: Enter Baptiſta and Lucentio: Pedant booted and bare headed.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Signior Baptiſta you are happilie met:
Sir, this is the Gentleman I told you of,
I pray you ſtand good father to me now,
Giue me Bianca for my Patrimony.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Soft ſon: ſir by your leaue, hauing come to Padua
To gather in ſome debts, my ſon Lucentio
Made me acquainted with a waightie cauſe
Of loue beteweene your daughter and himſelfe:
And for the good report I heare of you,
And for the loue he beareth to your daughter,
And ſhee to him: to ſtay him not too long,
I am content in a good fathers care.
To haue him matcht, and if you pleaſe to like
No worſe then I vpon ſome agreement
Me ſhall you finde readie and willing
With one conſent to haue her ſo beſtowed:
For curious I cannot be with you
Signior Baptiſta, of whom I heare ſo well.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Sir, pardon me in what I haue to ſay,
Your plainneſſe and your ſhortneſſe pleaſe me well
Right true it is your ſon Lucentio here
Doth loue my daughter and ſhe loueth him
Or both diſſemble deepely their affections:
And therefore if you ſay no more then this,
That like a father you will deale with him,
And paſſe my daughter a ſufficient dower,
The match is made and all is done,
Your ſonne ſhall haue my daughter with conſent.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: I thanke you ſir, where then doe you know beſt
We be affied and ſuch aſſurance tane,
As ſhall with either parts agreement ſtand.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Not in my houſe Lucentio for you know
Pitchers haue eares, and I haue manie ſeruants,
Beſides old Gremio is harkning ſtill,
And happilie we may be interrupted.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Then at my lodging, and it like you,
There doth my father lie: and there this night
Weele paſſe the buſineſſe priuately and well:
Send for your daughter by your ſeruant here,
My boy ſhall fetch the Scriuener preſentlie,
The worſt is this that at ſo ſlender warning,
You are like to haue a thin and ſlender pittance.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: It likes me well:
Cambio hie you home and bid Bianca make her readie ſtraight:
And if you will tell what hath hapned,
Lucentios father is arriued in Padua,
And how ſhe's like to be Lucentios wife.

sp.speaker: Biond.
sp.l: I pray the Gods ſhe may with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.l: Dallie not with the Gods, but get thee gone.
Signior Baptiſta ſhall I leade the way,
Welcome, one meſſe is like to be your cheere,
Come ſir we will better it in Piſa.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: I follow you. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: What ſaiſt thou Biondello.

sp.speaker: Biond.
sp.l: You ſaw my Maſter winke and laugh vpon you?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Biondello, what of that?

sp.speaker: Biond.
sp.p: Faith nothing: but has left me here behinde to expound the meaning or morrall of his ſignes and tokens.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I pray thee moralize them.

sp.speaker: Biond.
sp.p: Then thus: Baptiſta is ſafe talking with the deceiuing Father of a deceitfull ſonne.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: And what of him?

sp.speaker: Biond
sp.l: His daughter is to be brought by you to the ſupper.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: And then.

sp.speaker: Bion.
sp.p: The old Prieſt at Saint Lukes Church is at your command at all houres.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: And what of all this.

sp.speaker: Bion.
sp.p: I cannot tell, expect they are buſied about a counterfeit aſſurance: take you aſſurance of her. Cum preuilegio ad Impremendum ſolem, to th' Church take the Prieſt, Clarke, and ſome ſufficient honeſt witneſſes:
sp.l: If this bee not that you looke for, I haue no more to ſay,
But bid Bianca farewell for euer and a day.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Hear'ſt thou Biondello.

sp.speaker: Biond.
sp.p: I cannot tarrie: I knew a wench married in an afternoone as ſhe went to the Garden for Parſeley to ſtuffe a Rabit, and ſo may you ſir: and ſo adew ſir, my Maſter hath appointed me to goe to Saint Lukes to bid the Prieſt be readie to come againſt you come with your appendix.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I may and will if ſhe be ſo contented:
She will be pleasd, then wherefore ſhould I doubt:
Hap what hap may, Ile roundly go about her:
It ſhall go hard if Cambio go without her. Exit.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Come on a Gods name, once more towards our fathers:
Good Lord how bright and goodly ſhines the Moone.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: The Moone, the Sunne: it is not Moone-light now.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: I ſay it is the Moone that ſhines ſo bright.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: I know it is the Sunne that ſhine, ſo bright.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Now by my mothers ſonne, and that's my ſelfe,
It ſhall be moone, or ſtarre, or what I liſt,
Or ere I iourney to your Fathers houſe:
Goe on, and fetch our horſes backe againe
Euer more croſt and croſt nothing but croſt,

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: Say as he ſaies, or we ſhall neuer goe

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Forward I pray, ſince we haue come ſo farr,
And be it moone, or Sunne, or what you pleaſe:
And if you pleaſe to call it a ruſh Candle:
Henceforth I vowe it ſhall be ſo for me.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: I ſay it is the Moone.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: I know it is the Moone.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Nay then you lye: it is the bleſſed Sunne.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Then God be bleſt, it is the bleſſed ſun,
But ſunne it is not, when you ſay it is not.
And the Moone changes euen as your minde:
What you will haue it nam'd, euen that it is,
And ſo it ſhall be ſo for Katherine.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: Petruchio, goe thy wayes, the field is won.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Well, forward, forward thus the bowle ſhould run,
And not vnluckily againſt the Bias:
But ſoft: Company is comming here.
Good morrow gentle Miſtris, where away:
Tell mee ſweete Kate, and tell me truely too,
Haſt thou beheld a freſher Gentlewoman:
Such warre of white and red within her cheekes:
What ſtarrs do ſpangle heauen with ſuch beautie,
As thoſe two eyes become that heauenly face?
Faire louely Maide, once more good day to thee:
Sweete Kate embrace her for her beauties ſake.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: A will make the man mad to make the woman of him.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Yong budding Virgin, faire, and freſh, and ſweete,
Whether away, or whether is thy aboade?
Happy the parents of ſo faire a childe;
Happier the man whom fauourable ſtars
Alots thee for his louely bedfellow.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Why how now Kate, I hope thou art not mad,
This is a man old, wrinckled, faded, withered,
And not a Maiden, as thou ſaiſt he is.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Pardon old father my miſtaking eyes,
That haue bin ſo bedazled with the ſunne,
That euery thing I look on ſeemeth greene:
Now I perceiue thou are a reuerent Father:
Pardon I pray thee for my mad miſtaking.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Do good old grandſire, and with all make known
Which way thou trauelleſt if along with vs,
Wee ſhall be ioyfull of thy company▪

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Faire Sir, and you my merry Miſtris,
That with your ſtrange encounter much amaſde me:
My name is call'd Ʋincentio, my dwelling Piſa,
And bound I am to Padua, there to uiſite
A ſonne of mine, which long I haue not ſeene.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: What is his name?

sp.speaker: Vinc.
sp.l: Lucentio Gentle ſir.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Happily met the happier for thy ſonne:
And now by Law, as well as reuerent age,
I may intitle thee my louing Father,
The ſiſter to my wife, this Gentlewoman,
Thy Sonne by this hath married: wonder not,
Nor be not grieued, ſhe is of good eſteeme,
Her dowrie wealthie, and of worthie birth;
Beſide, ſo qualified, as may be ſeeme
The Spouſe of any noble Gentlewoman:
Let me imbrace with old Vincentio,
And wander we to ſee thy honeſt ſonne,
Who will of thy arriuall be full ioyous.

sp.speaker: Vinc.
sp.l: But is this true, or is it elſe your pleaſure,
Like pleaſant trauailors to breake a ieſt
Vpon the companie you ouertake?

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: I do aſſure thee father ſo it is.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Come goe along and ſee the truth hereof,
For our firſt merriment hath made thee iealous. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Well Petruchio, this has put me in heart;
Haue to my Widdow, and if ſhe froward,
Then haſt thou taught Hortenſio to be vntoward. Exit

div.stage: Enter Biondello, Lucentio and Bianca, Gremio is out before.

sp.speaker: Biond.
sp.l: Softly and ſwiftly ſir, for the Prieſt is ready.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I flie Biondello; but they may chance to neede thee at home therefore leaue vs. Exit.

sp.speaker: Biond,
sp.l: Nay faith' Ile ſee the Church a your backe,
And then come backe to my miſtris as ſoone as I can.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: I maruaile Cambio comes not all this while.

div.stage: Enter Petruchio, Kate, Vincentio, Grumio With attendants.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Sir heres the doore, this is Lucentios houſe,
My Fathers beares more toward the Market-place,
Thither muſt I and heere I leaue y • u ſir.

sp.speaker: Ʋin.
sp.l: You ſhall not chooſe but drinke before you go,
I thinke I ſhall command your welcome here;
And by all likelihood ſome cheere is toward. Knock.

sp.speaker: Grem.
sp.l: They're buſie within, you were beſt knocke lowder.

div.stage: Pedant lookes out of the window.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: What's he that knockes as he would beate downe the gate?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Is Signior Lucentio within ſir?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: He's within ſir, but not to be ſpoken withall.

sp.speaker: Vinc.
sp.p: What if a man bring him a hundred pound or two to make merrie withall.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Keepe your hundred pounds to your ſelfe, he ſhall neede none ſo long as I liue.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: Nay, I told you your ſonne was beloued in Padua: doe you heare ſir, to leaue friuolous circumſtances, I pray you tell Signior Lucentio that his Father is come from Piſa, and is heere at the doore to ſpeake with him.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Thou lieſt his Father is come from Padua, and here looking out of the window.

sp.speaker: Ʋin.
sp.l: Art thou his Father?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I ſir ſo his mother ſayes if I may beleeue her.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: Why how now Gentleman: why this is flat knauerie to take vpon you an other mans name.

sp.speaker: Peda.
sp.p: Lay hands on the villaine, I beleeue a meanes to cozen ſome bodie in this Citie vnder my countenance.

sp.speaker: Bion.
sp.p: I haue ſeene them in the Church together, God ſend them good ſh • pping: but who is heere? mine old Maſter Vincentio: now we are vndone and brought to nothing.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Come hither crackhempe.

sp.speaker: Bion.
sp.l: I hope I may chooſe Sir.

sp.speaker: Ʋin.
sp.l: Come hither you rogue, what haue you forgot mee?

sp.speaker: Biond.
sp.p: Forgot you, no ſir: I could not forget you, for I neuer ſaw you before in all my life.

sp.speaker: Vinc.
sp.p: What, you notorius villaine, didſt thou neuer ſee thy Miſtris father, Ʋincentio;

sp.speaker: Bion.
sp.p: What my worſhipfull old maſter? yet marrie ſir ſee where he lookes out of the window.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Iſt ſo indeede. He beates Biondello.

sp.speaker: Bion.
sp.l: Helpe, helpe, helpe, here's a mad man will murder me.

sp.speaker: Pedan.
sp.l: Help, ſonne, helpe Signior Baptiſta.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Prethee, Kate let's ſtand aſide and ſee the end of this controuerſie.

div.stage: Enter Pedant with ſeruants, Baptiſta, Tranio.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Sir what are you that offer to beate my ſeruant?

sp.speaker: Ʋinc.
sp.p: What am I ſir: nay what are you ſir: oh immortall Gods▪ oh fine villaine, a ſilken doublet, a veluet hoſe, a ſcarlet cloak and a copataine hat: oh I am vndone, I am vndone: while I plaie the good husband at home, my ſonne and my ſeruant ſpend all at the vniuerſitie.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: How now what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Bapt.
sp.l: What is the man lunaticke?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Sir, you ſeeme a ſober ancient Gentleman by your habit but your words ſhew you a mad man: why ſir, what cernes it you, if I weare Pearle and gold: I thanke my good father, I am able to maintaine it.

sp.speaker: Ʋin.
sp.l: Thy father: oh villaine, he is a Saile-maker in Bergamo.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.p: You Miſtake ſir, you miſtake ſir, praie what do you think is his name?

sp.speaker: Ʋin.
sp.p: His name, as if I knew not his name: I haue brought him vp euer ſince he was three yeeres old, and his name is Tronio.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Awaie, away mad aſſe, his name is Lucentio, and he is mine onelie ſonne and heire to the lands of me ſignior Ʋincentio.

sp.speaker: Ʋin.
sp.p: Lucentio, oh he hath murdred his Maſter; lay hold on him I charge you in the Dukes name: oh my ſonne, my ſonne: tell me thou villaine, where is my ſonne Lucentio?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Call forth an officer: Carrie this mad knaue to the Iaile: Father Baptiſta, I charge you ſee that he be forth comming.

sp.speaker: Ʋinc.
sp.l: Carrie mee to the Iaile?

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: Staie officer, he ſhall not go to priſon.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Talke not ſignior Gremio: I ſay he ſhall goe to priſon.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Take heede ſignior Baptiſta, leſt you be conicatcht in this buſineſſe: I dare ſweare this is the right Ʋincentio.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Sweare if thou dar'ſt,

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: Naie, I dare not ſweare it.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.l: Then thou wert beſt ſay that I am not Lucentio.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: Yes I know thee to be ſignior Lucentio.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Away with the dotard, to the Iaile with him.

sp.speaker: Ʋin.
sp.p: Thus ſtrangers may be haild and abuſd: oh monſtrous villaine.

sp.speaker: Bion.
sp.p: Oh we are ſpoil'd, and yonder he is, denie him, forſweare him, or elſe wee are all vndone.

div.stage: Exit Biondello, Tranio and Pedant as faſt as may be.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Pardon ſweete father. Kneele.

sp.speaker: Ʋin,
sp.l: Liues my ſweete ſonne?

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Pardon deere father.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: How haſt thou offended, where is Lucentio?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Heere's Lucentio right ſonne to the right Ʋincentio,
That haue by marriage made thy daughter mine,
While counterfeit ſuppoſes bleer'd thine eine.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: Heere's packing with a witneſſe to deceiue vs all.

sp.speaker: Ʋin.
sp.l: Where is that damned villaine Tranio,
That fac'd and braued me in this matter ſo?

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Why, tell me is not this my Cambio?

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Cambio is chang'd into Lucentio.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Loue wrought theſe miracles. Biancas loue
Made me exchange my ſtate with Tranio,
While he did beare my countenance in the Towne,
And happilie I haue arriued at the laſt
Vnto the wiſhed hauen of my bliſſe:
What Tranio did, my ſelfe enforſt him to:
Then pardon him ſweete Father for my ſake.

sp.speaker: Ʋin.
sp.p: Ile ſlit the villaines noſe that would haue ſent me to the Iaile.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.p: But doe you heare ſir, haue you married my daughter without asking my good will?

sp.speaker: Ʋin.
sp.p: Feare not Baptiſta, wee will content you go to: but I will in to be reueng'd for this villanie. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: And I to ſound the depth of this knauerie. Exit.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Looke not pale Bianca, thy father will not frowne.

sp.speaker: Gre,
sp.l: My cake is dough, but Ile in among the reſt,
Out of hope of all, but my ſhare of the feaſt.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Husband let's follow, to ſee the end of this adoe.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Firſt kiſſe me Kate, and wee will.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: What in the midſt of the ſtreete?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: What are thou aſham'd of me?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: No ſir, God forbid, but aſham'd to kiſſe.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Why then let's home againe: Come Sirralet's away.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Nay, I will giue thee a kiſſe, now pray Loue ſtay.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Is not this well? come my ſweete Kate.
Better once then neuer, for neuer too late. Exeunt.

div.head: Actus Quintus.
div.stage: Enter Baptiſta, Ʋincentio, Gremio, the Pedant, Lucentio, and Bianca, Tranio, Biondello Grumio, and widdow: The ſeruingmen with Tranio bringing in a Banquet.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: At laſt though long, our iarring notes agree,
And time it is when raging warre is come,
To ſmile at ſcapes and perils ouerblowne:
My faire Bianca bid my father welcome,
While I with ſelfe ſame kindneſſe welcome thine:
Brother Petruchio, ſiſter Katerina,
And thou Hortenſio with thy louing Widdow:
Feaſt with the beſt, and welcome to my houſe,
My banket is to cloſe our ſtomakes vp
After our great good cheere: pray you ſit downe,
For now wee ſit to chat as well as eate.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Nothing but ſit and ſit, and eate and eate.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Padua affoords this kindneſſe ſonne Petruchio.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Padua affords nothing but what is kinde.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: For both our ſakes I would that word were true.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Now for my life Hortenſio feares his Widow.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Then neuer truſt me if I be affeard.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: You are very ſenſible, and yet you miſſe my ſence:
I meane Hortentio is afeard of you.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: He that is giddie thinkes the world turns round.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Roundly replied.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Miſtris how meane you that?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Thus I conceiue by him.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Conceiues by me, how likes Hortenſio that?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: My Widdow ſayes, thus ſhe conceiues her tale.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Verie well mended: kiſſe him for that good Widdow.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: He that is giddie thinkes the world turnes round,
I pray you tell me what you meant by that.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Your husband being troubled with a ſhrew,
Meaſures my husbands ſorrow, by his woe:
And now you know my meaning.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: A verie meane meaning,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Right. I meane you.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: And I am meane indeed, reſpecting you.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: To her Kate.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: To her Widdow.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: A hundred marks, my Kate does put her down.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: That's my office

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Spoke like an Officer: ha to thee Lad.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: How likes Gremio theſe quicke witted folkes?

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: Beleeue me ſir, they But together well.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Head, and But an haſtie witted bodie,
Would ſay your Head and But were head and horne.

sp.speaker: Ʋin.
sp.l: I Miſtris Bride, hath that awakened you?

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: I, but not frighted me, therefore Ile ſleepe againe,

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Nay that you ſhall not ſince you haue begun:
Haue at you for a better Ieſt or too.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Am I your Bird, I meane to ſhift my buſh,
And then purſue me as you draw my Bow.
You are welcome all. Exit Bianca.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: She hath preuented me, here ſignior Tranio,
This bird you aim'd at, though you hit her not,
Therfore a health to all that ſhot and miſt.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Oh ſir, Lucentio ſlipt me like his Gray-hound,
Which runs himſelfe and catches for his Maſter.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: A good ſwift ſimile, but ſomething curriſh.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: 'Tis well ſir that you hunted for your ſelfe:
'Tis thought your Deere does hold you at a baye.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Oh, oh Pretuchio, Tranio hits you now.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I thanke thee for that gird good Tranio.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Confeſſe, confeſſe, hath he not hit you here?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: A has a litle gald me I confeſſe:
And as the Ieſt did glaunce away from me,
'Tis ten to one it maim'd you too out right.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Now in good ſadneſſe ſonne Petruchio,
I thinke thou haſt the verieſt ſhrew of all.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Well I ſay no: and therefore ſir, aſſurance,
Let's each one ſend vnto his wife,
And he whoſe wife is moſt obedient,
To come at firſt when he doth ſend for her,
Shall win the wager which we will propoſe.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: Content what's the wager?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Twentie crownes.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Twentie crownes.
Ile venture ſo much of my Hawke or Hound,
But twentie times ſo much vpon my Wife.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: A hundred then.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Content.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: A match 'tis done.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Who ſhall begin?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: That will I.
Goe Biondello, bid your Miſtris come to me.

sp.speaker: Bio.
sp.l: I goe. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Sonne Ile be you • halfe, Bianca comes.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Ile haue no halues: Ile beare it all my ſelfe.
How now, what newes?

sp.speaker: Bion.
sp.l: Sir, my Miſtris ſends you word
That ſhe is buſie, and ſhee cannot come.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: How? ſhe's buſie and ſhee cannot come: is that an anſwere?

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: I, and a kinde one too:
Praie God ſir your wife ſend you not a worſe.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: I hope better.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Sirra Biondello, goe and intreate my wife to come to mee forthwith. Exit. Bion.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Oh ho intreate her, nay then ſhe muſt needes come.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I am affraid ſir, doe what you can
Yours will not be intreated: Now where's my wife?

sp.speaker: Bion.
sp.l: She ſayes you haue ſome goodly Ieſt in hand,
She will not come: ſhe bids you come to her.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Worſe and worſe ſhe will not come:
Oh vild, intollerable, not to be indur'd:
Sirra Grumio, goe to your Miſtris,
Say I command her come to me. Exit.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I know her anſwere.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: She will not.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: The fouler fortune mine, and there an end.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Now by my hollidam here comes Katerina.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: What is your will ſir, that you ſend for me?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Where is your ſiſter, and Hortenſios wife?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: They ſit conferring by the Parler fire.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Goe fetch them hither, if they denie to come,
Swinge me them foundly forth vnto their husbands:
Away I ſay, and bring them hither ſtraight.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Here is a wonder, if you talke of a wonder.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: And ſo it is: I wonder what it boads

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Marrie peace it boads, and loue, and quiet life,
An awfull rule, and right ſupremacie:
And to be ſhort, what not, that's ſweete and happie.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Now faire befall thee good Petruchio;
The wager thou haſt won, and I will adde
Vnto their loſſes twentie thouſand crownes,
Another dowrie to another daughter,
For ſhe is chang'd as ſhe had neuer bin.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Nay, I will win my wager better yet,
And ſhew more ſigne of her obedience,
Her new built vertue and obedience.
See where ſhe comes, and brings your froward Wiues
As priſoners to her womanlie perſwaſion:
Katerine, that Cap of yours becomes you not,
Off with that bable, throw it vnder foote.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Lord let me neuer haue a cauſe to ſigh,
Till I be brought to ſuch a ſillie paſſe.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Fie what a fooliſh dutie call you this?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I would your dutie were as fooliſh too:
The wiſdome of your dutie faire Bianca,
Hath coſt me fiue hundred crownes ſince ſupper time,

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: The more foole you for laying on my dutie.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Katherine I charge thee tell theſe head-ſtrong women, what dutie they doe owe their Lords and husbands.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Come, come, your mocking: we will haue no telling.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Come on I ſay, and firſt begin with her,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: She ſhall not.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I ſay ſhe ſhall, and firſt begin with her.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Fie, fie, vnknit that threatning vnkind brow,
And dart not ſcornefull glances from thoſe eies,
To wound thy Lord, thy King, thy Gouernour.
It blots thy beautie, as froſts doe bite the Meades,
Confounds thy fame, as whirlewindes ſhake faire budds,
And in no ſence is meete or amiable.
A woman mou'd, is like a fountaine troubled,
Maddie, ill ſeeming thicke, bereft of beautie,
And while it is ſo, none ſo drie or thirſtie
Will daigne to ſip or touch one drop of it.
Thy husband is thy Lord▪ thy life, thy Keeper,
Thy head, thy ſoueraigne: one that cares for thee,
And for thy maintenance: Commits his bodie
To painfull labour, both by ſea and land:
To watch the night in ſtormes, the day in cold,
Whi'ſt thou ly'ſt warme at home, ſecure and ſafe,
And craues no other tribute at thy hands,
But loue, fare lookes, and true obedience;
Too litle payment for ſo great a debt.
Such dutie as the ſubiect owes the Prince,
Euen ſuch a woman oweth to her huſband:
And when ſhe is froward, peeuiſh, ſullen, ſower,
And not obedient to his honeſt will:
What is ſhe but a foule contending Rebell,
And graceleſſe Traitour to her louing Lord?
I am a ſham'd that women are ſo ſimple,
To offer warre, where they ſhould kneele for peace:
Or ſeeke for rule, ſupremacie, and ſway,
When they are bound to ſerue, loue, and obay.
Why are our bodies ſoft, and weake, and ſmooth,
Vnapt to toyle, and trouble in the world,
But that our ſoft conditions, and our harts.
Should well agree with our externall parts?
Come, come, you froward and vnable wormes
My minde hath bin as bigge as one of yours,
My heart as great, my reaſon haplie more,
To bandie word for word, and frowne for frowne;
But now I ſee our Launces are but ſtrawes:
Our ſtrength as weake, our weakeneſſe paſt compare,
That ſeeming to be moſt, which we indeed leaſt are.
Then vale your ſtomackes, for it is no boote,
And place your hands below your husbands foote:
In token of which dutie, if he pleaſe,
My hand is readie may it do him eaſe.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Why ther's a wench: come on, and kiſſe me Kate.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Well go thy wayes old Lad for thou ſhalt ha't.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: 'Tis a good hearing, when children are toward.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: But a harſh hearing, when women are froward,

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Come Kate, wee'l to bed,
We three are married, but you two are ſped.
'Twas I won the wager though you hit the white.
And being a winner, God giue you good night,

sp.speaker: Horten.
sp.l: Now go thy wayes thou haſt tam'd a curſt Shrow.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: 'Tis a wonder by your leaue, ſhe will tam'd ſo.
